Subject: Testing multiple versions of a class
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=IqJ8vd_fJSa2SfwEw0PcJ35OHNpEfI3MbCmocYCW4wij1MRp

XOM currently includes two versions of one class, nu.xom.Text. 
Externally the versions are identical. i.e. the public APIs are the 
same. Internally one is optimized for speed and one is optimized for 
size. Which one is used is chosen by a compile time flag. i.e. you can 
compile for speed or you can compile for size but not both at once.

Can anyone suggest how one might reliably and automatically test this? 
The project is built from Ant. I'd like "ant test" to to run the tests 
with both the speedy and compact versions.

I have thought pretty hard about whether it's possible to use separate 
classes with a common abstract superclass to make the implementation 
decision at runtime.  So far, though, neither I nor anyone else has been 
able to figure out how to do that without either duplicating storage in 
both classes or relaxing class invariants and preconditions, neither of 
which is acceptable.

--
